oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Caring for the wounded after the Battle of New Orleans
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Color engraving, "Scene After the Battle of New Orleans," illustrates U.S. soldiers and militiamen caring for the wounded. At left, a British officer is lifted onto a stretcher. Background shows American parapets made of cotton bales. A U.S. flag waves in the background. From John Frost and William Croome, "Pictorial Life of Andrew Jackson." Two uncolored versions, titled "General Jackson Relieving the Wounded British After the Battle," are also available.

Though it was fought after the Treaty of Ghent was signed, the Battle of New Orleans (January 8, 1815) was a decisive victory for the United States in its war against Great Britain. Major-General Andrew Jackson commanded American troops, and British forces fought under the command of Major-General Sir Edward Pakenham. The War of 1812, also known as the ""Second American Revolution,"" brought greater American self-confidence and national pride.
